item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Wildlife Traders Find a Home Online
item.description: Social media and online forums are increasingly being used in China as platforms to help wildlife sellers and buyers find each other, posing new challenges for law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A baby pangolin rescued from smugglers was released in the forest by an Indonesian conservation officer. The animal is in demand in China for its meat and for its scales, which some believe have medicinal qualities.

item.title: Militants Divide Kenyan Miners by Religion, Then Kill the Christians
item.description: It was the second such massacre in northern Kenya in the past month. The Shabab militant group took responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Security officers gathered near victims’ bodies at a quarry in northern Kenya on Tuesday.

item.title: NATO to Create Interim Rapid Response Force to Counter Russia
item.description: The alliance will start the unit, to be made up initially of about 4,000 German, Dutch and Norweigian soldiers, next year mainly to repel potential attacks by Russia.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Rosh Haayin Journal: Lessons From an Ancient Time When Recyclers Walked the Earth
item.description: Archaeologists working at Qesem Cave in Israel discovered tools that indicated a prehistoric commitment to limiting waste.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flint stones that indicate prehistoric recycling were found in Qesem Cave and examined at Tel Aviv University.

item.title: French Lawmakers Vote to Recognize Palestinian State
item.description: The nonbinding vote by the lower house of Parliament was the latest in a series in Europe that have underlined growing frustration with Israeli policies.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Tipping Point: The Next Big Climate Question: Will India Follow China?
item.description: China’s leaders have self-interested reasons to combat pollution, as their recent pledge suggests. India’s leaders may have the same reasons.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GREENSTONE
item.media:description: Smog hangs in the air over a dump in New Delhi. India has a serious air pollution problem that it is finally starting to confront.

item.title: Open Source: Three Detained in India in Harassment of Sisters Who Fought Back
item.description: The young men are accused of sexually harassing two sisters on a bus in the Indian state of Haryana in an incident caught on video.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Three men accused of sexual harassing two sister in the Indian state of Haryana last week, after they were detained.

item.title: Russia Forecasts a Recession in 2015, Signaling a Toll From Sanctions and Oil Prices
item.description: Moscow revised its forecast for next year to show a contraction of 0.8 percent, compared with a previous projection of 1.2 percent growth.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Outside a currency exchange agency in Moscow. The ruble fell against the dollar after the Russian government predicted the economy would fall into a recession next year.

item.title: Iraqi Government and Kurds Reach Deal to Share Oil Revenues
item.description: The agreement, which could unite Iraq in the face of a Sunni insurgency, covers the sharing of oil revenues with the autonomous Kurdish region.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The disputed region of Kirkuk, Iraq, will provide 300,000 barrels of oil a day under the deal.

item.title: Netanyahu Fires Centrist Israeli Ministers and Calls for New Elections
item.description: The move comes after days of intense political bickering between the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his coalition partners.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Netanyahu Fires Centrist Cabinet Ministers and Calls for New Elections
item.description: The move comes after days of intense political bickering between the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his coalition partners.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: French Vote Urges Recognition of Palestinian State
item.description: France's lower house of Parliament voted Tuesday to urge the government to recognize a Palestinian state, in the hope that it would speed up peace efforts after decades of conflict.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ukraine and Rebel Group Say They’ll Recommit to a Cease-Fire
item.description: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said the military and the Luhansk People’s Republic agreed to order a cease-fire starting Friday.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Tugce Albayrak's Death Rattles Germany
item.description: The death of a Turkish-German student who tried to stop a man from taunting two girls came as Germany debates its new, multicultural society.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: A French Town Reels After Teenage Girl Vanishes, Apparently to Join Jihadists
item.description: A small but growing number of teenage girls in Europe, enticed by Internet recruiters, have shown amazing determination in their efforts to join jihadists, experts say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The housing projects in Bethoncourt, France, where a 15-year-old girl named Soukaïna lived before traveling to Istanbul and then Gaziantep, a Turkish city known as a jihadist gateway to Syria.

item.title: Lebanon Is Said to Detain Wife and Child of ISIS Leader
item.description: An official said the woman thought to be Abu Bakr al Baghdadi’s wife was still being questioned and that it remained unclear how much she may know about the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: No Agreement Reached on Syrian No-Fly Zone
item.description: Turkey is continuing to push the Obama administration to impose a no-fly zone or safe area along the Turkish-Syrian border, administration officials said Monday, but obstacles remain.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Shatila Journal: Palestinian Refuge for 6 Decades, Now Flooded From Syria
item.description: The Syrian civil war has driven a wave of Syrians into Lebanon, roughly doubling the population of the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main market in the Shatila refugee camp, one of two such rapidly growing settlements on the edge of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: James Leibold on Ethnic Policies in China
item.description: Mr. Leibold’s research focuses on the Chinese government’s policies toward ethnic minorities and their effects on people’s daily lives. He recently returned from a trip to the western region of Xinjiang,
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Japanese Right Attacks Newspaper on the Left, Emboldening War Revisionists
item.description: The Asahi Shimbun’s formal retraction of articles about “comfort women” in World War II has led to an assault on the newspaper and on the view that Japan forced women into sexual slavery.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Takashi Uemura, a former reporter for The Asahi Shimbun, in front of the university where he teaches.
